newsitem.title: JAPAN: Nissan aims to raise its RV share.
newsitem.headline: Nissan aims to raise its RV share.

text.p: Nissan Motor Co Ltd aims to raise its share of the domestic recreational vehicle market with a new heavy sport-utility vehicle that was previewed on Tuesday.

"We want to raise our share (in Japan's heavy sport-utility vehicle market) by two to three percentage points to about 27 percent through sales of the new Terrano Regulus," Nissan president Yoshikazu Hanawa told reporters at a preview of the new model.
The vehicle opens a new market -- the luxury version of a heavy sport-utility vehicle.

Japan's overall demand for heavy sport-utility vehicles stands at about 18,600 per month. Nissan said no other Japanese makers have a model in the same market segment. Regulus will be positioned in the same segment as Chrysler Corp's Grand Cherokee.
The Terrano Regulus was developed as a new generation personal sport-utility vehicle with an image of premium quality, Hanawa said.
Regulus features a cleaner, more silent but powerful 3.2-litre intercooler-turbo diesel engine, Hanawa said.
"We set a conservative sales target -- 1,000 a month. I think we can expect more though," Hanawa said. The domestic selling price of Regulus will range from 2.763 million to 3.399 million yen.
Terrano Regulus was aimed at people in their 40s and 50s, another Nissan official said. The vehicle is is equipped with dual airbags and anti-lock brake system as standard.
Hanawa said Nissan will also start selling the Terrano Regulus in the autumn in the United States through its Infiniti luxury car sales network.
Nissan plans to export more than 1,000 Terrano Regulus a month, to be marketed as Infiniti QX4 to compete with Toyota's Land Cruiser and Chrysler's Grand Cherokee, another Nissan official said.
Toyota sells its Land Cruiser in the United States under the model name of LX450 at about 1,000 a month.
Chrysler now sells about 30,000 Grand Cherokees a month in the United States.
